docs.lead_paragraph: With volunteer guards on either side of her, a young blond woman walks through a crowd of protesters and enters a health clinic, most likely to have an abortion. A version of this scene appears in no less than three recent films. In ''Critical Choices,'' a stultifyingly evenhanded movie made for Showtime (tonight at 11:40), the woman entering the clinic is a married mother of two, scraping by financially. Pamela Reed, as an anti-abortion protester, yells at her, ''If it has brain waves and a heartbeat it's alive!'' In ''If These Walls Could Talk,'' (made for HBO and available on home video in February), an unmarried student enters a clinic, confused about how to reconcile her Roman Catholic upbringing with her feeling that having an abortion is the best decision she can make.

headline.main: Choices and No Choices In the Abortion Wars

docs.abstract: Caryn James reviews made-for-television movies Critical Choices (Showtime) and If These Walls Could Talk (HBO), and motion picture Citizen Ruth, all of which deal with issue of abortion; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With volunteer guards on either side of her, a young blond woman walks through a crowd of protesters and enters a health clinic, most likely to have an abortion. A version of this scene appears in no less than three recent films. In ''Critical...

docs.lead_paragraph: Banking on a vibrant economy, states once reluctant to change their welfare systems are devising ambitious ways to push aid recipients into the jobs at the heart of the new welfare law. Even states with strong liberal traditions, like West Virginia, Hawaii and Minnesota, and states that have long lagged in grappling with welfare policy, like Texas and South Carolina, are charging ahead out of concern that if they do not act now to shift people into the work force, it will be much more difficult later, when the economy turns sluggish.

headline.main: Previously Reluctant States Moving on Welfare Changes

docs.abstract: States previously reluctant to change welfare systems are banking on vibrant economy and devising ambitious ways to push aid recipients into jobs at heart of new welfare law; even states with strong liberal traditions, like West Virginia, Hawaii and Minnesota, and states that have long lagged in grappling with policy, like Texas and South Carolina, are charging ahead out of concern that failure to act expeditiously to shift people into work force could make it more difficult later, when economy turns sluggish; plans being drawn include offering employers wage subsidies and relocating recipients to areas where they can find jobs (M)
